sections.heading: What is Perspective in Japanese?
sections.content:
Japanese grammar requires you to choose your viewpoint - are you looking from inside or outside? This affects which giving/receiving verbs you use and how you express actions.

Key Concept: Japanese distinguishes between:

内 (うち) "Inside" - Your in-group (you, family, close friends) 外 (そと) "Outside" - Out-group (others, strangers, distant people)

友達が私にくれた (in-group receives) "My friend gave (to) me" 田中さんは山田さんにあげた (out-group to out-group) "Tanaka gave to Yamada"

children.heading: Your In-Group Includes:
children.content:
Always:

Yourself (私) Your immediate family (when talking to outsiders) Your company (when talking to outsiders)

Context-dependent:

Close friends (in casual contexts) Your team/department (in work contexts) Your classmates (in school contexts)

children.heading: Out-Group Includes:
children.content:
Always:

Strangers Other people's families Other companies/organizations

Context-dependent:

Your family (when talking within family) Your company (when talking to your boss)

children.heading: From In-Group → Out-Group: あげる
children.content: 私は田中さんにプレゼントをあげた "I gave a present to Tanaka" 兄が友達にゲームをあげた "My brother gave a game to his friend" (兄 is my in-group)

children.heading: From Out-Group → In-Group: くれる
children.content: 田中さんが私にプレゼントをくれた "Tanaka gave me a present" 友達が弟にゲームをくれた "A friend gave my younger brother a game" (弟 is my in-group)

children.heading: Between Out-Group Members: あげる
children.content: 田中さんは山田さんにプレゼントをあげた "Tanaka gave Yamada a present" (Neither is my in-group)

sections.heading: The "Me-Centric" View
sections.content: Japanese grammar is egocentric - it revolves around your perspective:

children.heading: You are the center:
children.content: Out-group ↓ [くれる (receive)] ↓ ★ YOU (In-group) ★ ↓ [あげる (give)] ↓ Out-group

children.heading: Verbs change based on direction:
children.content:
Toward you/in-group:

くれる (they give to me) もらう (I receive from them)

Away from you/in-group:

あげる (I give to them) やる (I give to juniors)

children.heading: Talking to Outsiders
children.content:
Your family = In-group:

母が先生に本をさしあげました "My mother gave a book to the teacher" (母 = in-group, giving up to superior) 先生が弟に本をくださいました "The teacher gave a book to my brother" (弟 = in-group, receiving from superior)

children.heading: Talking Within Family
children.content:
The speaker's position matters:

Older to younger:

お母さんが私にくれた "Mom gave (it) to me" (Mom gives down to me)

Younger to older:

お母さんにあげた "I gave (it) to mom" (I give up to mom)

children.heading: Talking to Outsiders
children.content:
Your company = In-group:

弊社からカタログをお送りします "Our company will send you a catalog" (We give to outsiders) お客様からご意見をいただきました "We received feedback from the customer" (We receive from outsiders - humble)

children.heading: Talking to Your Boss
children.content:
Your boss = Out-group (higher status):

部長に報告書をさしあげました "I gave the report to the department head" (I give up to superior) 部長が資料をくださいました "The department head gave me materials" (Superior gives down to me)

children.heading: Rule 1: Identify the In-Group
children.content:
Ask yourself: "Who am I aligned with?"

私の友達が田中さんにあげた "My friend gave to Tanaka" (My friend = in-group, uses あげる) 田中さんが私の友達にくれた "Tanaka gave to my friend" (My friend = in-group, uses くれる)

children.heading: Rule 2: Check the Direction
children.content: Toward in-group: くれる Away from in-group: あげる Between out-groups: あげる

children.heading: Rule 3: Consider Social Hierarchy
children.content:
Even within direction, hierarchy matters:

先生がくださった (honorific くれる) "The teacher gave (to me)" 友達がくれた (neutral くれる) "My friend gave (to me)"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Wrong verb for direction
children.content: Wrong: 友達が私にあげた ❌ Right: 友達が私にくれた ✓ "My friend gave to me" Direction is TOWARD me, must use くれる!

children.heading: Mistake 2: Ignoring in-group
children.content: Unnatural: 田中さんが私の弟にあげた ⚠️ Natural: 田中さんが私の弟にくれた ✓ "Tanaka gave to my younger brother" Your brother is in-group!

children.heading: Mistake 3: Wrong perspective in requests
children.content: Less natural: 田中さんに手伝ってあげてください ⚠️ Natural: 田中さんを手伝ってあげてください ✓ "Please help Tanaka" Or better: 田中さんを手伝ってください ✓

sections.heading: Empathy and Perspective
sections.content: Japanese perspective shows who you empathize with :

children.heading: Empathizing with your family:
children.content: 母が先生に叱られた "My mother was scolded by the teacher" (You feel bad for your mother)

children.heading: Neutral observation:
children.content: 先生が母を叱った "The teacher scolded my mother" (Neutral statement, no strong empathy)

children.heading: Between two outsiders:
children.content: 田中さんは山田さんに本をあげた "Tanaka gave Yamada a book"

children.heading: One is in-group:
children.content: 田中さんは私の弟に本をくれた "Tanaka gave my brother a book" (Empathy with brother = in-group)

sections.heading: Perspective with てあげる/てくれる/てもらう

children.heading: 〜てあげる - I do for out-group
children.content: 友達を手伝ってあげた "I helped my friend" (I → friend)

children.heading: 〜てくれる - Out-group does for me
children.content: 友達が手伝ってくれた "My friend helped me" (Friend → me)

children.heading: 〜てもらう - I receive action from out-group
children.content: 友達に手伝ってもらった "I had my friend help me" (Friend → me, my benefit)

children.heading: Why perspective matters:
children.content:
Japanese culture emphasizes:

Awareness of relationships - Who is inside/outside your circle Social hierarchy - Adjusting language to status Group identity - Aligning with your in-group

Using the wrong verb shows:

Lack of awareness of relationships Unclear group loyalty Improper social positioning

children.heading: Direction Flow Chart
children.content: Out-group Person ↓ くれる/くださる (they give TO me) ★ ME ★ ↓ あげる/さしあげる (I give TO them) Out-group Person Out-group ←あげる→ Out-group (neither involves me)

children.heading: Tip 1: Start with yourself
children.content:
Ask: "Am I giving or receiving?"

Giving out → あげる/さしあげる Receiving in → くれる/もらう/いただく

children.heading: Tip 2: Check the recipient
children.content:
Ask: "Is the recipient me or my in-group?"

Yes → くれる/くださる No → あげる/さしあげる

children.heading: Tip 3: When confused, simplify
children.content:
If you're unsure:

Avoid using these verbs Use plain verb forms Add context to clarify

Instead of: 友達が本をくれた Simple: 友達から本をもらった "I received a book from my friend"

children.heading: Scenario 1: Gift Exchange
children.content: Your friend gives you a gift: 友達がプレゼントをくれた ✓ "My friend gave me a present" You give your friend a gift: 友達にプレゼントをあげた ✓ "I gave my friend a present"

children.heading: Scenario 2: Family Help
children.content: Your mom helps your sister (talking to outsider): 母が妹を手伝ってあげた ✓ "My mother helped my sister" (Both in-group, giving outward perspective) Friend helps your sister: 友達が妹を手伝ってくれた ✓ "My friend helped my sister" (Friend → in-group sister)

children.heading: Scenario 3: Work Situation
children.content: You give report to boss: 部長にレポートをさしあげた ✓ "I gave the report to my boss" Boss gives you advice: 部長がアドバイスをくださった ✓ "My boss gave me advice" Colleague gives another colleague something: 田中さんは山田さんに資料をあげた ✓ "Tanaka gave materials to Yamada"

sections.heading: Advanced: Multiple Perspectives
sections.content:
Sometimes you can choose perspective:

Neutral (outsider view): 母は先生に本をさしあげた "My mother gave a book to the teacher" Empathetic (mother's view): 母は先生に本をさしあげた Same sentence, different mental stance

The grammar is the same, but your mental alignment differs!

sections.heading: Summary Table
sections.content: | Giver | Receiver | Verb | | --------- | ------------------- | ---------- | | Me | Out-group | あげる | | Me | Superior | さしあげる | | Out-group | Me | くれる | | Superior | Me | くださる | | Me | Out-group (receive) | もらう | | Me | Superior (receive) | いただく | | In-group | Out-group | あげる | | Out-group | In-group | くれる | | Out-group | Out-group | あげる |

sections.heading: Related Grammar Points
sections.content: Giving: あげる/やる/さしあげる - Giving verbs Receiving: もらう/いただく - Receiving verbs Favor: くれる/くださる - Someone gives to me Direction of Actions - てあげる/てくれる/てもらう Honorific language - Politeness levels Passive voice - Related perspective shifts
